ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A solid overview of the history of Cuba from colonial days to the present.
I was able to learn intensively about the history of Cuba from the 1800s to the present time. We talked about different concepts of liberation, economics, political cartoons, news articles, etc.
history of Cuba from colonialism onward, cultural production of Cuba (poetry, short stories, music, cartoons)
Learned a lot about Cuban history!
I learned about the history of Cuba, a much more thorough perspective than the narrative that is pushed by US propaganda.

I now have a much deeper understanding of Cubas history and culture. I could speak at length about nuances in the historial record of Cuba and its relationship with the United States. I also have a better context for understanding Cuban popular culture.
I developed a thorough understanding of the history of Cuba.
Knowledge of Cuban history and discussions about Cuban cultural developments, particularly relating to Cuban independence, American imperialism, and the Cuban Revolution.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the biggest strengths of the course is the variety of sources that Professor Laguna includes: history books and articles, sure, but also short stories, poems, songs, videos, archival sources from Yale libraries, and chats with professors and journalists he knows outside of Yale. The course is able to move quickly through a lot of history but also with a good amount of depth into each week's theme/era. Perhaps the only weakness is that the class didn't get to go to Cuba as some past years have done \_()_/
I really enjoyed the different readings and multimedia that we were able to analyze. I hope that in future years we can get more guest speakers and a trip to Cuba!

strengths: guest speakers, Professor Laguna is so kind and engaging, midterm builds towards final which is very useful, balance of history and culture
weaknesses: we don't go to Cuba anymore over spring break
Laguna is amazing! The readings are super fun and informative. I wish we had more class time and got to go to Cuba
Well-organized and facilitated very well.
I loved the course and its structure, I would just try to leave more space for student discussion

Strengths: The various source materials from this course were one of its main strengths, particularly the weekly readings which complemented the central history text by Gott. Professor Laguna also did an excellent job; he made this course very engaging and made himself available to give feedback and provide assistance to ensure students' success.
Weaknesses: My only complaint is that we weren't able to go to Cuba this year :( Otherwise a terrific class!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely, especially to anyone interested in Cuba/US/Latin American/Atlantic history or in Cuban and Cuban-American culture.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has thought about political systems and how it is seen in other countries.
yes if you are interested in Latin America and the Caribbean or looking for an easy ER&M seminar
Yes, this is one of those classes that if you get into it you take it no questions asked. Its probably one of the best courses I have taken at Yale
Yes, it was a very interesting class that broadened my perspective on Cuba.
Yes!! Great course and format.

Absolutely! If you're Cuban or Cuban-American, you will of course enjoy all that this course has to offer. If you're an ER&M or LAST major, definitely worth taking this course, too!! Cuba is a country with an incredibly rich history and culture that is very interesting to learn about. Prof Laguna is a great professor and this class was always so much fun to go to. I will just note that because of the long history covered in a relatively short amount of time, the class functions as a survey course and classes could sometimes feel lecture-y rather than an opportunity for students to have seminar-style discussions. But this isn't necessarily a weakness in my eyes, though it might be for other students!

Yes! If you have even a passing interest in learning more deeply about Cuba, this is the perfect opportunity. Professor Laguna is phenomenal, and I especially enjoyed being able to learn via the contributions of other students to seminar.
Absolutely!

Yes! Especially if you come from a Cuban background, this course is a great way to learn more about Cuban history from a more nuanced perspective than the traditional story told by our parents/grandparents. Professor Laguna is also great and covers the material in a fun and engaging way.

extras.title: ER&M 293 01/LAST 293 01 - History and Culture of Cuba
